qas.question: Which neighbors did Halych develop trade relations with?
Who united the two previously separated principalities?
In what year did Mstislavich defeat the Kiev?
Which neighbors did Halych not develop trade relations with?
Who did not unit the two principalities?
Who did not conquer Kiev in 1202?

plausible_answers.text: King of Poland a metropolitan for his Russian subjects

qas.question: What did the patriarch of the Western Orthodox Church grant?

context: To the southwest, the principality of Halych had developed trade relations with its <a0_0><b4_0>Polish, Hungarian and Lithuanian<b4_0/><a0_0/> neighbours and emerged as the local successor to Kievan Rus'. In 1199, <a1_0><b5_0><b6_0>Prince Roman Mstislavich<b6_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/> united the two previously separate principalities. In <a2_0>1202<a2_0/> he conquered Kiev, and assumed the title of Grand Duke of Kievan Rus', which was held by the rulers of Vladimir-Suzdal since 1169. His son, Prince Daniil (r. <b7_0>1238–1264<b7_0/>) looked for support from the West. He accepted a crown as a "Rex Rusiae" ("King of Russia") from the Roman papacy, apparently doing so without breaking with Constantinople. In 1370, the patriarch of the Eastern Orthodox Church in Constantinople granted the <b8_0>King of Poland a metropolitan for his Russian subjects<b8_0/>. Lithuanian rulers also requested and received a metropolitan for Novagrudok shortly afterwards. <a3_0>Cyprian<a3_0/>, a candidate pushed by the Lithuanian rulers, became Metropolitan of Kiev in 1375 and metropolitan of Moscow in 1382; this way the church in the Russian countries was reunited for some time. In 1439, Kiev became the seat of a separate "Metropolitan of Kiev, Galich and all Rus'" for all Greek Orthodox Christians under Polish-Lithuanian rule.
